{{DISPLAYTITLE:L<sup>''p''</sup> space}} In [[mathematics]], the '''L<sup>''p''</sup> spaces''' are [[function space]]s defined using a natural generalization of the [[Norm (mathematics)#p-norm|''p''-norm]] for finite-dimensional [[vector space]]s. They are sometimes called '''Lebesgue spaces''', named after [[Henri Lebesgue]] {{harv|Dunford|Schwartz|1958|loc=III.3}}, although according to the [[Nicolas Bourbaki|Bourbaki]] group {{harv|Bourbaki|1987}} they were first introduced by [[Frigyes Riesz]] {{harv|Riesz|1910}}. '''L<sup>''p''</sup> spaces''' form an important class of [[Banach space]]s in [[functional analysis]], and of [[topological vector space]]s. Because of their key role in the mathematical analysis of measure and probability spaces, Lebesgue spaces are used also in the theoretical discussion of problems in physics, statistics, finance, engineering, and other disciplines.
==Applications==
===Statistics=== In [[statistics]], measures of [[central tendency]] and [[statistical dispersion]], such as the [[mean]], [[median]], and [[standard deviation]], are defined in terms of ''L''<sup>''p''</sup> metrics, and measures of central tendency can be characterized as [[Central tendency#Solutions to variational problems|solutions to variational problems]].
In penalized regression, 'L1 penalty' and 'L2 penalty' refer to penalizing either the [[Taxicab geometry|''L''<sup>1</sup> norm]] of a solution's vector of parameter values (i.e. the sum of its absolute values), or its ''L''<sup>2</sup> norm (its [[Norm (mathematics)#Euclidean norm|Euclidean length]]). Techniques which use an L1 penalty, like [[LASSO]], encourage solutions where many parameters are zero. Techniques which use an L2 penalty, like [[Tikhonov regularization|ridge regression]], encourage solutions where most parameter values are small. [[Elastic net regularization]] uses a penalty term that is a combination of the ''L''<sup>1</sup> norm and the ''L''<sup>2</sup> norm of the parameter vector.
===Hausdorff–Young inequality=== The [[Fourier transform]] for the real line (or, for [[periodic functions]], see [[Fourier series]]), maps ''L<sup>p</sup>''('''R''') to ''L<sup>q</sup>''('''R''') (or ''L<sup>p</sup>''('''T''') to ℓ<sup>''q''</sup>) respectively, where 1 ≤ ''p'' ≤ 2 and 1/''p'' + 1/''q'' = 1. This is a consequence of the [[Riesz–Thorin theorem|Riesz–Thorin interpolation theorem]], and is made precise with the [[Hausdorff–Young inequality]].
By contrast, if ''p'' > 2, the Fourier transform does not map into ''L<sup>q</sup>''.
===Hilbert spaces=== [[Hilbert space]]s are central to many applications, from [[quantum mechanics]] to [[stochastic calculus]]. The spaces ''L''<sup>2</sup> and ℓ<sup>2</sup> are both Hilbert spaces. In fact, by choosing a Hilbert basis (i.e., a maximal orthonormal subset of ''L''<sup>2</sup> or any Hilbert space), one sees that all Hilbert spaces are isometric to ℓ<sup>2</sup>(''E''), where ''E'' is a set with an appropriate cardinality.
==The {{math|''p''}}-norm in finite dimensions== [[Image:Vector-p-Norms qtl1.svg|thumb|right|Illustrations of [[unit circle]]s (see also [[superellipse]]) in different {{math|''p''}}-norms (every vector from the origin to the unit circle has a length of one, the length being calculated with length-formula of the corresponding {{math|''p''}}).]]
The length of a vector {{math|''x'' {{=}} (''x''<sub>1</sub>, ''x''<sub>2</sub>, ..., ''x<sub>n</sub>'')}} in the {{mvar|n}}-dimensional [[real number|real]] [[vector space]] {{math|'''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>}} is usually given by the [[Euclidean norm]]:
:<math> \left\| x \right\| _2 = \left( {x_1}^2 + {x_2}^2 + \dotsb + {x_n}^2 \right)^{1/2} .</math>
The Euclidean distance between two points {{mvar|x}} and {{mvar|y}} is the length {{math|{{!!}}''x'' − ''y''{{!!}}<sub>2</sub>}} of the straight line between the two points. In many situations, the Euclidean distance is insufficient for capturing the actual distances in a given space. An analogy to this is suggested by taxi drivers in a grid street plan who should measure distance not in terms of the length of the straight line to their destination, but in terms of the [[taxicab geometry|rectilinear distance]], which takes into account that streets are either orthogonal or parallel to each other. The class of {{mvar|p}}-norms generalizes these two examples and has an abundance of applications in many parts of [[mathematics]], [[physics]], and [[computer science]].
===Definition=== For a [[real number]] {{math|''p'' ≥ 1}}, the '''{{math|''p''}}-norm''' or '''{{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}}-norm''' of {{math|''x''}} is defined by
:<math> \left\| x \right\| _p = \left( |x_1|^p + |x_2|^p + \dotsb + |x_n|^p \right) ^{1/p} .</math> The absolute value bars are unnecessary when ''p'' is a rational number and, in reduced form, has an even numerator.
The Euclidean norm from above falls into this class and is the 2-norm, and the 1-norm is the norm that corresponds to the [[taxicab geometry|rectilinear distance]].
The '''{{math|''L''<sup>∞</sup>}}-norm''' or [[Chebyshev distance|maximum norm]] (or uniform norm) is the limit of the {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}}-norms for <math>p \rightarrow \infty</math>. It turns out that this limit is equivalent to the following definition:
:<math> \left\| x \right\| _\infty = \max \left\{ |x_1|, |x_2|, \dotsc, |x_n| \right\} </math>
See [[L-infinity]].
For all {{math|''p'' ≥ 1}}, the {{mvar|p}}-norms and maximum norm as defined above indeed satisfy the properties of a "length function" (or [[norm (mathematics)|norm]]), which are that: *only the zero vector has zero length, *the length of the vector is positive homogeneous with respect to multiplication by a scalar ([[Homogeneous function#Positive homogeneity|positive homogeneity]]), and *the length of the sum of two vectors is no larger than the sum of lengths of the vectors ([[triangle inequality]]). Abstractly speaking, this means that {{math|'''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>}} together with the {{mvar|p}}-norm is a [[Banach space]]. This Banach space is the '''{{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}}-space''' over {{math|'''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>}}.
====Relations between {{math|''p''}}-norms==== The grid distance or rectilinear distance (sometimes called the "[[Manhattan distance]]") between two points is never shorter than the length of the line segment between them (the Euclidean or "as the crow flies" distance). Formally, this means that the Euclidean norm of any vector is bounded by its 1-norm:
:<math> \left\| x \right\| _2 \leq \left\| x \right\| _1 .</math>
This fact generalizes to {{mvar|p}}-norms in that the {{mvar|p}}-norm {{math|{{!!}}''x''{{!!}}<sub>''p''</sub>}} of any given vector {{math|''x''}} does not grow with {{math|''p''}}:
:{{math|{{!!}}''x''{{!!}}<sub>''p''+''a''</sub> ≤ {{!!}}''x''{{!!}}<sub>''p''</sub>}} for any vector {{math|''x''}} and real numbers {{math|''p'' ≥ 1}} and {{math|''a'' ≥ 0}}. (In fact this remains true for {{math|0 < ''p'' < 1}} and {{math|''a'' ≥ 0}}.)
For the opposite direction, the following relation between the 1-norm and the 2-norm is known:
:<math> \left\| x \right\| _1 \leq \sqrt{n} \left\| x \right\| _2 .</math>
This inequality depends on the dimension {{mvar|n}} of the underlying vector space and follows directly from the [[Cauchy–Schwarz inequality]].
In general, for vectors in {{math|'''C'''<sup>''n''</sup>}} where {{math|0 < ''r'' < ''p''}}:
:<math> \left\| x \right\| _p \leq \left\| x \right\| _r \leq n^{ (1/r - 1/p) } \left\| x \right\| _p .</math>
===When {{math|0 < ''p'' < 1}}=== [[Image:Astroid.svg|thumb|right|[[Astroid]], unit circle in {{math|''p'' {{=}} {{sfrac|2|3}}}} metric]] In {{math|'''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>}} for {{math|''n'' > 1}}, the formula
:<math> \|x\| _p = \left( |x_1| ^p + |x_2| ^p + \cdots + |x_n|^p \right) ^{1/p} </math>
defines an absolutely [[homogeneous function]] for {{math|0 < ''p'' < 1}}; however, the resulting function does not define a norm, because it is not [[subadditivity|subadditive]]. On the other hand, the formula
:<math> |x_1|^p + |x_2|^p + \dotsb + |x_n|^p</math>
defines a subadditive function at the cost of losing absolute homogeneity. It does define an [[F-space|F-norm]], though, which is homogeneous of degree {{mvar|p}}.
Hence, the function :<math>d_p(x,y) = \sum_{i=1}^n |x_i-y_i|^p</math>
defines a [[metric space|metric]]. The metric space {{math|('''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>, ''d''<sub>''p''</sub>)}} is denoted by ℓ<sub>''n''</sub><sup>''p''</sup>.
Although the {{mvar|p}}-unit ball ''B''<sub>''n''</sub><sup>''p''</sup> around the origin in this metric is "concave", the topology defined on {{math|'''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>}} by the metric {{math|''d<sub>p</sub>''}} is the usual vector space topology of {{math|'''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>}}, hence ℓ<sub>''n''</sub><sup>''p''</sup> is a [[locally convex]] topological vector space. Beyond this qualitative statement, a quantitative way to measure the lack of convexity of ℓ<sub>''n''</sub><sup>''p''</sup> is to denote by {{math|''C<sub>p</sub>''(''n'')}} the smallest constant {{mvar|C}} such that the multiple ''C'' ''B''<sub>''n''</sub><sup>''p''</sup> of the {{mvar|p}}-unit ball contains the convex hull of ''B''<sub>''n''</sub><sup>''p''</sup>, equal to ''B''<sub>''n''</sub><sup>1</sup>. The fact that for fixed {{math|''p'' < 1}} we have
:<math> C_p(n) = n^{1/p - 1} \to \infty, \qquad \text{as } n \to \infty </math>
shows that the infinite-dimensional sequence space {{math|''ℓ<sup>p</sup>''}} defined below, is no longer locally convex.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
===When ''p'' = 0=== There is one ℓ<sub>0</sub> norm and another function called the ℓ<sub>0</sub> "norm" (with quotation marks).
The mathematical definition of the ℓ<sub>0</sub> norm was established by [[Banach]]'s ''[[Theory of Linear Operations]]''. The [[F-space|space]] of sequences has a complete metric topology provided by the [[F-space|F-norm]]
:<math>(x_n) \mapsto \sum_n 2^{-n} \frac{|x_n|}{1 +|x_n|},</math>
which is discussed by Stefan Rolewicz in ''Metric Linear Spaces''.<ref name="RolewiczControl">{{Citation|title=Functional analysis and control theory: Linear systems|last=Rolewicz |first=Stefan|year=1987| isbn=90-277-2186-6| publisher=D. Reidel Publishing Co.; PWN—Polish Scientific Publishers|oclc=13064804|edition=Translated from the Polish by Ewa Bednarczuk| series=Mathematics and its Applications (East European Series)|location=Dordrecht; Warsaw|volume=29|pages=xvi+524| mr=920371| doi=10.1007/978-94-015-7758-8}}{{page needed|date=April 2016}}</ref> The ℓ<sub>0</sub>-normed space is studied in functional analysis, probability theory, and harmonic analysis.
Another function was called the ℓ<sub>0</sub> "norm" by [[David Donoho]]—whose quotation marks warn that this function is not a proper norm—is the number of non-zero entries of the vector ''x''. Many authors [[abuse of terminology|abuse terminology]] by omitting the quotation marks. Defining [[zero to the power of zero|{{nowrap|1=0<sup>0</sup> = 0}}]], the zero "norm" of ''x'' is equal to
:<math>|x_1|^0 + |x_2|^0 + \cdots + |x_n|^0 .</math>
[[File:Lp space animation.gif|alt=An animated gif of p-norms 0.1 through 2 with a step of 0.05.|thumb|An animated gif of p-norms 0.1 through 2 with a step of 0.05.]] This is not a [[norm (mathematics)|norm]] because it is not [[Homogeneous function|homogeneous]]. Despite these defects as a mathematical norm, the non-zero counting "norm" has uses in [[scientific computing]], [[information theory]], and [[statistics]]–notably in [[compressed sensing]] in [[signal processing]] and computational [[harmonic analysis]].
==The {{math|''p''}}-norm in countably infinite dimensions and {{math|''ℓ<sup> p</sup>''}} spaces== {{Details|Sequence space}} The {{mvar|p}}-norm can be extended to vectors that have an infinite number of components, which yields the space {{math|''ℓ<sup> p</sup>''}}. This contains as special cases: *{{math|''ℓ''<sup> 1</sup>}}, the space of sequences whose series is [[absolute convergence|absolutely convergent]], *{{math|''ℓ''<sup> 2</sup>}}, the space of '''square-summable''' sequences, which is a [[Hilbert space]], and *{{math|''ℓ''<sup> ∞</sup>}}, the space of [[bounded sequence]]s.
The space of sequences has a natural vector space structure by applying addition and scalar multiplication coordinate by coordinate. Explicitly, the vector sum and the scalar action for infinite [[sequence]]s of real (or [[complex number|complex]]) numbers are given by:
:<math>\begin{align} & (x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n, x_{n+1},\ldots)+(y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_n, y_{n+1},\ldots) \\ = {} & (x_1+y_1, x_2+y_2, \ldots, x_n+y_n, x_{n+1}+y_{n+1},\ldots), \\[6pt] & \lambda \cdot \left (x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n, x_{n+1},\ldots \right) \\ = {} & (\lambda x_1, \lambda x_2, \ldots, \lambda x_n, \lambda x_{n+1},\ldots). \end{align}</math>
Define the {{mvar|p}}-norm:
:<math> \left\| x \right\| _p = \left( |x_1|^p + |x_2|^p + \cdots +|x_n|^p + |x_{n+1}| ^p + \cdots \right) ^{1/p}</math>
Here, a complication arises, namely that the [[series (mathematics)|series]] on the right is not always convergent, so for example, the sequence made up of only ones, {{math|(1, 1, 1, ...)}}, will have an infinite {{mvar|p}}-norm for {{math|1 ≤ ''p'' < ∞}}. The space {{math|''ℓ<sup> p</sup>''}} is then defined as the set of all infinite sequences of real (or complex) numbers such that the {{mvar|p}}-norm is finite.
One can check that as {{math|''p''}} increases, the set {{math|''ℓ<sup> p</sup>''}} grows larger. For example, the sequence
:<math>\left(1, \frac{1}{2}, \ldots, \frac{1}{n}, \frac{1}{n+1},\ldots\right)</math>
is not in {{math|''ℓ''<sup> 1</sup>}}, but it is in {{math|''ℓ<sup> p</sup>''}} for {{math|''p'' > 1}}, as the series
:<math>1^p + \frac{1}{2^p} + \cdots + \frac{1}{n^p} + \frac{1}{(n+1)^p}+\cdots,</math>
diverges for {{math|''p'' {{=}} 1}} (the [[harmonic series (mathematics)|harmonic series]]), but is convergent for {{math|''p'' > 1}}.
One also defines the {{math|∞}}-norm using the [[supremum]]:
:<math> \left\| x \right\| _\infty = \sup(|x_1|, |x_2|, \dotsc, |x_n|,|x_{n+1}|, \ldots)</math>
and the corresponding space {{math|''ℓ''<sup> ∞</sup>}} of all bounded sequences. It turns out that<ref>{{Citation | last1=Maddox | first1=I. J. | title=Elements of Functional Analysis | publisher=CUP | location=Cambridge | edition=2nd | year=1988}}, page 16</ref>
:<math> \left\| x \right\| _\infty = \lim_{ p \to \infty } \left\| x \right\| _p </math>
if the right-hand side is finite, or the left-hand side is infinite. Thus, we will consider {{math|''ℓ<sup> p</sup>''}} spaces for {{math|1 ≤ ''p'' ≤ ∞}}.
The {{math|''p''}}-norm thus defined on {{math|''ℓ<sup> p</sup>''}} is indeed a norm, and {{math|''ℓ<sup> p</sup>''}} together with this norm is a [[Banach space]]. The fully general {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} space is obtained—as seen below — by considering vectors, not only with finitely or countably-infinitely many components, but with "''arbitrarily many components''"; in other words, [[function (mathematics)|functions]]. An [[integral]] instead of a sum is used to define the {{math|''p''}}-norm.
=={{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} spaces== An {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} space may be defined as a space of functions for which the ''p''-th power of the [[absolute value]] is [[Lebesgue integrable]],<ref>We could just say "integrable". Since the integrand is a non-negative real-valued function, there is no difference between having a finite Lebesgue integral and having a finite [[improper integral]] (as there is say for the function sin(''x'')/''x'' when integrated over the entire real line).</ref> where functions which agree almost everywhere are identified. More generally, let {{math|1 ≤ ''p'' < ∞}} and {{math|(''S'', Σ, ''μ'')}} be a [[measure space]]. Consider the set of all [[measurable function]]s from {{mvar|S}} to {{math|'''C'''}} or {{math|'''R'''}} whose [[absolute value]] raised to the {{mvar|p}}-th power has a finite integral, or equivalently, that
:<math>\|f\|_p \equiv \left( \int_S |f|^p\;\mathrm{d}\mu \right)^{1/p}<\infty</math>
The set of such functions forms a [[vector space]], with the following natural operations:
:<math>\begin{align} (f+g)(x) &= f(x)+g(x), \\ (\lambda f)(x) &= \lambda f(x) \end{align}</math>
for every scalar {{mvar|λ}}.
That the sum of two {{mvar|p}}-th power integrable functions is again {{mvar|p}}-th power integrable follows from the inequality
:<math> \|f + g\|_p^p \leq 2^{p-1} \left (\|f\|_p^p + \|g\|_p^p \right ).</math>
(This comes from the convexity of <math>t\mapsto t^p</math> for <math>p\ge1</math>.)
In fact, more is true. ''[[Minkowski inequality|Minkowski's inequality]]'' says the [[triangle inequality]] holds for {{math|{{!!}} · {{!!}}<sub>''p''</sub>}}. Thus the set of {{mvar|p}}-th power integrable functions, together with the function {{math|{{!!}} · {{!!}}<sub>''p''</sub>}}, is a [[seminorm]]ed vector space, which is denoted by <math>\mathcal{L}^p(S,\, \mu)</math>.
{{anchor|kernel}} This can be made into a [[normed vector space]] in a standard way; one simply takes the [[quotient space (topology)|quotient space]] with respect to the [[kernel (set theory)|kernel]] of {{math|{{!!}} · {{!!}}<sub>''p''</sub>}}. Since for any measurable function {{math| ''f'' }}, we have that {{math|{{!!}} ''f'' {{!!}}<sub>''p''</sub> {{=}} 0}} if and only if {{math| ''f''  {{=}} 0}} [[almost everywhere]], the kernel of {{math|{{!!}} · {{!!}}<sub>''p''</sub>}} does not depend upon {{mvar|p}},
:<math>\mathcal{N} \equiv \{f : f = 0 \ \mu\text{-almost everywhere} \} = \ker(\|\cdot\|_p) \qquad\forall\ 1\leq p < \infty</math>
In the quotient space, two functions {{math| ''f'' }} and {{mvar|g}} are identified if {{math| ''f''  {{=}} ''g''}} almost everywhere. The resulting normed vector space is, by definition,
:<math>L^p(S, \mu) \equiv \mathcal{L}^p(S, \mu) / \mathcal{N}</math>
For {{math|''p'' {{=}} ∞}}, the space {{math|''L''<sup>∞</sup>(''S'', ''μ'')}} is defined as follows. We start with the set of all measurable functions from {{mvar|S}} to {{math|'''C'''}} or {{math|'''R'''}} which are bounded. Again two such functions are identified if they are equal almost everywhere. Denote this set by {{math|''L''<sup>∞</sup>(''S'', ''μ'')}}. For a function {{math| ''f'' }} in this set, the [[essential supremum]] of its absolute value serves as an appropriate norm:
:<math>\|f\|_\infty \equiv \inf \{ C\ge 0 : |f(x)| \le C \text{ for almost every } x \}. </math>
As before, if there exists {{math|''q'' < ∞}} such that {{math| ''f''  ∈ ''L''<sup>∞</sup>(''S'', ''μ'') ∩ ''L<sup>q</sup>''(''S'', ''μ'')}}, then
:<math>\|f\|_\infty = \lim_{p\to\infty}\|f\|_p.</math>
For {{math|1 ≤ ''p'' ≤ ∞, ''L<sup>p</sup>''(''S'', ''μ'')}} is a [[Banach space]]. The fact that {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} is complete is often referred to as the [[Riesz-Fischer theorem]]. Completeness can be checked using the convergence theorems for [[Lebesgue integral]]s.
When the underlying measure space {{mvar|S}} is understood, {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''S'', ''μ'')}} is often abbreviated {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''μ'')}}, or just {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}}. The above definitions generalize to [[Bochner space]]s.
===Special cases=== Similar to the {{math|ℓ<sup>''p''</sup>}} spaces, {{math|''L''<sup>2</sup>}} is the only [[Hilbert space]] among {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} spaces. In the complex case, the inner product on {{math|''L''<sup>2</sup>}} is defined by
:<math> \langle f, g \rangle = \int_S f(x) \overline{g(x)} \, \mathrm{d}\mu(x)</math>
The additional inner product structure allows for a richer theory, with applications to, for instance, [[Fourier series]] and [[quantum mechanics]]. Functions in {{math|''L''<sup>2</sup>}} are sometimes called '''[[quadratically integrable function]]s''', '''square-integrable functions''' or '''square-summable functions''', but sometimes these terms are reserved for functions that are square-integrable in some other sense, such as in the sense of a [[Riemann integral]] {{harv|Titchmarsh|1976}}.
If we use complex-valued functions, the space {{math|''L''<sup>∞</sup>}} is a [[commutative]] [[C*-algebra]] with pointwise multiplication and conjugation. For many measure spaces, including all sigma-finite ones, it is in fact a commutative [[von Neumann algebra]]. An element of {{math|''L''<sup>∞</sup>}} defines a [[bounded operator]] on any {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} space by [[multiplication operator|multiplication]].
For {{math|1 ≤ ''p'' ≤ ∞}} the {{math|ℓ<sup>''p''</sup>}} spaces are a special case of {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} spaces, when {{math|''S'' {{=}} [[Natural number|'''N''']]}}, and {{mvar|μ}} is the [[counting measure]] on {{math|'''N'''}}. More generally, if one considers any set {{mvar|S}} with the counting measure, the resulting {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} space is denoted {{math|ℓ<sup>''p''</sup>(''S'')}}. For example, the space {{math|ℓ<sup>''p''</sup>('''Z''')}} is the space of all sequences indexed by the integers, and when defining the {{mvar|p}}-norm on such a space, one sums over all the integers. The space {{math|ℓ<sup>''p''</sup>(''n'')}}, where {{mvar|n}} is the set with {{mvar|n}} elements, is {{math|'''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>}} with its {{mvar|p}}-norm as defined above. As any Hilbert space, every space {{math|''L''<sup>2</sup>}} is linearly isometric to a suitable {{math|ℓ<sup>2</sup>(''I'')}}, where the cardinality of the set {{mvar|I}} is the cardinality of an arbitrary Hilbertian basis for this particular {{math|''L''<sup>2</sup>}}.
==Properties of ''L''<sup>''p''</sup> spaces==
===Dual spaces=== The [[dual space#Continuous dual space|dual space]] (the Banach space of all continuous linear functionals) of {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''μ'')}} for {{math|1 < ''p'' < ∞}} has a natural isomorphism with {{math|''L<sup>q</sup>''(''μ'')}}, where {{mvar|q}} is such that {{math| {{sfrac|1|''p''}} + {{sfrac|1|''q''}} {{=}} 1}} (i.e. <math> q = \frac{p}{p-1}</math>). This isomorphism associates {{math|''g'' ∈ ''L<sup>q</sup>''(''μ'')}} with the functional {{math|''κ<sub>p</sub>''(''g'') ∈ ''L<sup>p</sup>''(''μ'')<sup>∗</sup>}} defined by
:<math>f \mapsto \kappa_p(g)(f)=\int f g \, \mathrm{d}\mu\ \ </math> for every <math>f \in L^p(\mu)</math>
The fact that {{math|''κ<sub>p</sub>''(''g'')}} is well defined and continuous follows from [[Hölder's inequality]]. {{math|''κ<sub>p</sub>'' : ''L<sup>q</sup>''(''μ'') → ''L<sup>p</sup>''(''μ'')<sup>∗</sup>}} is a linear mapping which is an [[isometry]] by the [[Hölder's inequality#Extremal equality|extremal case]] of Hölder's inequality. It is also possible to show (for example with the [[Radon–Nikodym theorem]], see<ref>{{Citation | last1=Rudin | first1=Walter | author1-link=Walter Rudin | title=Real and Complex Analysis | publisher=Tata McGraw-Hill | location=New Delhi | edition=2nd | year=1980 |isbn=9780070542341}}, Theorem 6.16</ref>) that any {{math|''G'' ∈ ''L<sup>p</sup>''(''μ'')<sup>∗</sup>}} can be expressed this way: i.e., that {{math|''κ<sub>p</sub>''}} is ''onto''. Since {{math|''κ<sub>p</sub>''}} is onto and isometric, it is an [[isomorphism]] of [[Banach space]]s. With this (isometric) isomorphism in mind, it is usual to say simply that {{math|''L<sup>q</sup>''}} is the dual Banach space of {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}}.
For {{math|1 < ''p'' < ∞}}, the space {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''μ'')}} is [[reflexive space|reflexive]]. Let {{math|''κ<sub>p</sub>''}} be as above and let {{math|''κ<sub>q</sub>'' : ''L<sup>p</sup>''(''μ'') → ''L<sup>q</sup>''(''μ'')<sup>∗</sup>}} be the corresponding linear isometry. Consider the map from {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''μ'')}} to {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''μ'')<sup>∗∗</sup>}}, obtained by composing {{math|''κ<sub>q</sub>''}} with the [[dual space#Transpose of a continuous linear map|transpose]] (or adjoint) of the inverse of {{math|''κ<sub>p</sub>''}}:
:<math>j_p : L^p(\mu) \overset{\kappa_q}{\longrightarrow} L^q(\mu)^* \overset{\left(\kappa_p^{-1}\right)^*}{\longrightarrow} L^p(\mu)^{**}</math>
This map coincides with the [[Reflexive space#Definitions|canonical embedding]] {{mvar|J}} of {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''μ'')}} into its bidual. Moreover, the map {{math|''j<sub>p</sub>''}} is onto, as composition of two onto isometries, and this proves reflexivity.
If the measure {{mvar|μ}} on {{mvar|S}} is [[sigma-finite]], then the dual of {{math|''L''<sup>1</sup>(''μ'')}} is isometrically isomorphic to {{math|''L''<sup>∞</sup>(''μ'')}} (more precisely, the map {{math|''κ''<sub>1</sub>}} corresponding to {{math|''p'' {{=}} 1}} is an isometry from {{math|''L''<sup>∞</sup>(''μ'')}} onto {{math|''L''<sup>1</sup>(''μ'')<sup>∗</sup>}}).
The dual of {{math|''L''<sup>∞</sup>}} is subtler. Elements of {{math|''L''<sup>∞</sup>(''μ'')<sup>∗</sup>}} can be identified with bounded signed ''finitely'' additive measures on {{mvar|S}} that are [[absolutely continuous]] with respect to {{mvar|μ}}. See [[ba space]] for more details. If we assume the axiom of choice, this space is much bigger than {{math|''L''<sup>1</sup>(''μ'')}} except in some trivial cases. However, [[Saharon Shelah]] proved that there are relatively consistent extensions of [[Zermelo–Fraenkel set theory]] (ZF + [[Axiom of dependent choice|DC]] + "Every subset of the real numbers has the [[Baire property]]") in which the dual of {{math|''ℓ''<sup>∞</sup>}} is {{math|''ℓ''<sup>1</sup>}}.<ref>{{Citation|title=Handbook of Analysis and its Foundations|last=Schechter |first=Eric|year=1997| publisher=Academic Press Inc.|location=London}} See Sections 14.77 and 27.44–47</ref>
===Embeddings=== Colloquially, if {{math|1 ≤ ''p'' < ''q'' ≤ ∞}}, then {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''S'', ''μ'')}} contains functions that are more locally singular, while elements of {{math|''L<sup>q</sup>''(''S'', ''μ'')}} can be more spread out. Consider the Lebesgue measure on the half line {{math|(0, ∞)}}. A continuous function in {{math|''L''<sup>1</sup>}} might blow up near 0 but must decay sufficiently fast toward infinity. On the other hand, continuous functions in {{math|''L''<sup>∞</sup>}} need not decay at all but no blow-up is allowed. The precise technical result is the following.<ref name="VillaniEmbeddings">{{Citation|title=Another note on the inclusion {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''μ'') ⊂ ''L<sup>q</sup>''(''μ'')}}|last=Villani |first=Alfonso|year=1985| journal=Amer. Math. Monthly|volume=92 |number=7 |pages=485–487 |doi=10.2307/2322503 |mr=801221}}</ref> Suppose that {{math|0 < ''p'' < ''q'' ≤ ∞}}. Then:
#{{math|''L<sup>q</sup>''(''S'', ''μ'') ⊂ ''L<sup>p</sup>''(''S'', ''μ'')}} iff {{mvar|S}} does not contain sets of finite but arbitrarily large measure, and #{{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''S'', ''μ'') ⊂ ''L<sup>q</sup>''(''S'', ''μ'')}} iff {{mvar|S}} does not contain sets of non-zero but arbitrarily small measure.
Neither condition holds for the real line with the Lebesgue measure. In both cases the embedding is continuous, in that the identity operator is a bounded linear map from {{math|''L<sup>q</sup>''}} to {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} in the first case, and {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} to {{math|''L<sup>q</sup>''}} in the second. (This is a consequence of the [[closed graph theorem]] and properties of {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} spaces.) Indeed, if the domain {{mvar|S}} has finite measure, one can make the following explicit calculation using [[Hölder's inequality]]
:<math>\ \|\mathbf{1}f^{p}\|_1 \le \|\mathbf{1}\|_{q/(q-p)} \|f^{p}\|_{q/p} </math> leading to :<math>\ \|f\|_p \le \mu(S)^{1/p - 1/q} \|f\|_q </math>.
The constant appearing in the above inequality is optimal, in the sense that the [[operator norm]] of the identity {{math|''I'' : ''L<sup>q</sup>''(''S'', ''μ'') → ''L<sup>p</sup>''(''S'', ''μ'')}} is precisely
:<math>\|I\|_{q,p} = \mu(S)^{1/p - 1/q}</math>
the case of equality being achieved exactly when {{math| ''f''  {{=}} 1}} {{mvar|μ}}-a.e.
===Dense subspaces=== Throughout this section we assume that: {{math|1 ≤ ''p'' < ∞}}.
Let {{math|(''S'', Σ, ''μ'')}} be a measure space. An ''integrable simple function'' {{math| ''f'' }} on {{mvar|S}} is one of the form
:<math>f = \sum_{j=1}^n a_j \mathbf{1}_{A_j}</math>
where {{math|''a<sub>j</sub>''}} is scalar, {{math|''A<sub>j</sub>'' ∈ Σ}} has finite measure and <math>{\mathbf 1}_{A_j}</math> is the [[indicator function]] of the set <math>A_j</math>, for {{math|''j'' {{=}} 1, ..., ''n''}}. By construction of the [[Lebesgue integration|integral]], the vector space of integrable simple functions is dense in {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''S'', Σ, ''μ'')}}.
More can be said when {{mvar|S}} is a [[Metrization theorem|metrizable]] [[topological space]] and {{math|Σ}} its [[Borel algebra|Borel {{mvar|σ}}–algebra]], i.e., the smallest {{mvar|σ}}–algebra of subsets of {{mvar|S}} containing the [[open set]]s.
Suppose {{math|''V'' ⊂ ''S''}} is an open set with {{math|''μ''(''V'') < ∞}}. It can be proved that for every Borel set {{math|''A'' ∈ Σ}} contained in {{mvar|V}}, and for every {{math|''ε'' > 0}}, there exist a closed set {{mvar|F}} and an open set {{mvar|U}} such that
:<math>F \subset A \subset U \subset V \quad \text{and} \quad \mu(U) - \mu(F) = \mu(U \setminus F) < \varepsilon</math>
It follows that there exists {{mvar|φ}} continuous on {{mvar|S}} such that
:<math>0 \le \varphi \le \mathbf{1}_V \quad \text{and} \quad \int_S |\mathbf{1}_A - \varphi| \, \mathrm{d}\mu < \varepsilon</math>
If {{mvar|S}} can be covered by an increasing sequence {{math|(''V<sub>n</sub>'')}} of open sets that have finite measure, then the space of {{mvar|p}}–integrable continuous functions is dense in {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''S'', Σ, ''μ'')}}. More precisely, one can use bounded continuous functions that vanish outside one of the open sets {{math|''V<sub>n</sub>''}}.
This applies in particular when {{math|''S'' {{=}} '''R'''<sup>''d''</sup>}} and when {{mvar|μ}} is the Lebesgue measure. The space of continuous and compactly supported functions is dense in {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''('''R'''<sup>''d''</sup>)}}. Similarly, the space of integrable ''step functions'' is dense in {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''('''R'''<sup>''d''</sup>)}}; this space is the linear span of indicator functions of bounded intervals when {{math|''d'' {{=}} 1}}, of bounded rectangles when {{math|''d'' {{=}} 2}} and more generally of products of bounded intervals.
Several properties of general functions in {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''('''R'''<sup>''d''</sup>)}} are first proved for continuous and compactly supported functions (sometimes for step functions), then extended by density to all functions. For example, it is proved this way that translations are continuous on {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''('''R'''<sup>''d''</sup>)}}, in the following sense:
:<math>\forall f \in L^p (\mathbf{R}^d): \qquad \left \|\tau_t f - f \right \|_p \to 0, \quad \text{ as } \mathbf{R}^d \ni t \to 0,</math>
where
:<math> (\tau_t f)(x) = f(x - t).</math>
=={{math|''L<sup>p</sup>'' (0 < ''p'' < 1)}}== Let {{math|(''S'', Σ, ''μ'')}} be a measure space. If {{math|0 < ''p'' < 1}}, then {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''μ'')}} can be defined as above: it is the vector space of those measurable functions {{math| ''f'' }} such that
:<math>N_p(f) = \int_S |f|^p\, d\mu < \infty.</math>
As before, we may introduce the {{mvar|p}}-norm {{math|{{!!}} ''f'' {{!!}}<sub>''p''</sub> {{=}} ''N<sub>p</sub>''( ''f'' )<sup>1/''p''</sup>}}, but {{math|{{!!}} · {{!!}}<sub> ''p''</sub>}} does not satisfy the triangle inequality in this case, and defines only a [[quasi-norm]]. The inequality {{math|(''a'' + ''b'')<sup> ''p''</sup> ≤ ''a<sup> p</sup>'' + ''b<sup> p</sup>''}}, valid for {{math|''a'', ''b'' ≥ 0}} implies that {{harv|Rudin|1991|loc=§1.47}}
:<math>N_p(f+g)\le N_p(f) + N_p(g)</math>
and so the function
:<math>d_p(f,g) = N_p(f-g) = \|f - g\|_p^p</math>
is a metric on {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''μ'')}}. The resulting metric space is [[complete space|complete]]; the verification is similar to the familiar case when {{math|''p'' ≥ 1}}.
In this setting {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} satisfies a ''reverse Minkowski inequality'', that is for {{math|''u'', ''v''}} in {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}}
:<math> \||u|+|v|\|_p\geq \|u\|_p+\|v\|_p</math>
This result may be used to prove [[Clarkson's inequalities]], which are in turn used to establish the [[uniformly convex space|uniform convexity]] of the spaces {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} for {{math|1 < ''p'' < ∞}} {{harv|Adams|Fournier|2003}}.
The space {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} for {{math|0 < ''p'' < 1}} is an [[F-space]]: it admits a complete translation-invariant metric with respect to which the vector space operations are continuous. It is also [[locally bounded]], much like the case {{math|''p'' ≥ 1}}. It is the prototypical example of an [[F-space]] that, for most reasonable measure spaces, is not [[locally convex]]: in {{math|''ℓ<sup> p</sup>''}} or {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''([0, 1])}}, every open convex set containing the {{math|0}} function is unbounded for the {{mvar|p}}-quasi-norm; therefore, the {{math|0}} vector does not possess a fundamental system of convex neighborhoods. Specifically, this is true if the measure space {{mvar|S}} contains an infinite family of disjoint measurable sets of finite positive measure.
The only nonempty convex open set in {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''([0, 1])}} is the entire space {{harv|Rudin|1991|loc=§1.47}}. As a particular consequence, there are no nonzero linear functionals on {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''([0, 1])}}: the dual space is the zero space. In the case of the [[counting measure]] on the natural numbers (producing the sequence space {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''μ'') {{=}} ''ℓ<sup> p</sup>''}}), the bounded linear functionals on {{math|''ℓ<sup> p</sup>''}} are exactly those that are bounded on {{math|''ℓ''<sup> 1</sup>}}, namely those given by sequences in {{math|''ℓ''<sup> ∞</sup>}}. Although {{math|''ℓ<sup> p</sup>''}} does contain non-trivial convex open sets, it fails to have enough of them to give a base for the topology.
The situation of having no linear functionals is highly undesirable for the purposes of doing analysis. In the case of the Lebesgue measure on {{math|'''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>}}, rather than work with {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} for {{math|0 < ''p'' < 1}}, it is common to work with the [[Hardy space]] {{math|''H<sup> p</sup>''}} whenever possible, as this has quite a few linear functionals: enough to distinguish points from one another. However, the [[Hahn–Banach theorem]] still fails in {{math|''H<sup> p</sup>''}} for {{math|''p'' < 1}} {{harv|Duren|1970|loc=§7.5}}.
==={{math|''L''<sup>0</sup>}}, the space of measurable functions=== The vector space of (equivalence classes of) measurable functions on {{math|(''S'', Σ, ''μ'')}} is denoted {{math|''L''<sup>0</sup>(''S'', Σ, ''μ'')}} {{harv|Kalton|Peck|Roberts|1984}}. By definition, it contains all the {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}}, and is equipped with the topology of ''[[convergence in measure]]''. When {{mvar|μ}} is a probability measure (i.e., {{math|''μ''(''S'') {{=}} 1}}), this mode of convergence is named ''[[convergence in probability]]''.
The description is easier when {{mvar|μ}} is finite. If {{mvar|μ}} is a finite measure on {{math|(''S'', Σ)}}, the {{math|0}} function admits for the convergence in measure the following fundamental system of neighborhoods
:<math>V_\varepsilon = \Bigl\{ f : \mu \bigl(\{x : |f(x)| > \varepsilon \} \bigr) < \varepsilon \Bigr\}, \qquad \varepsilon > 0</math>
The topology can be defined by any metric {{mvar|d}} of the form
:<math>d(f, g) = \int_S \varphi \bigl( |f(x) - g(x)| \bigr) \, \mathrm{d}\mu(x)</math>
where {{mvar|φ}} is bounded continuous concave and non-decreasing on {{math|[0, ∞)}}, with {{math|''φ''(0) {{=}} 0}} and {{math|''φ''(''t'') > 0}} when {{math|''t'' > 0}} (for example, {{math|''φ''(''t'') {{=}} min(''t'', 1))}}. Such a metric is called [[Paul Lévy (mathematician)|Lévy]]-metric for {{math|''L''<sup>0</sup>}}. Under this metric the space {{math|''L''<sup>0</sup>}} is complete (it is again an F-space). The space {{math|''L''<sup>0</sup>}} is in general not locally bounded, and not locally convex.
For the infinite Lebesgue measure {{mvar|λ}} on {{math|'''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>}}, the definition of the fundamental system of neighborhoods could be modified as follows
:<math>W_\varepsilon = \left\{ f : \lambda \left(\left\{ x : |f(x)| > \varepsilon \text{ and } |x| < \frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right\} \right) < \varepsilon \right\}</math>
The resulting space {{math|''L''<sup>0</sup>('''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>, ''λ'')}} coincides as topological vector space with {{math|''L''<sup>0</sup>('''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>, ''g''(''x'') d''λ''(x))}}, for any positive {{mvar|λ}}–integrable density {{mvar|g}}.
==Weak ''L<sup>p</sup>''== Let (''S'', ''Σ'', ''μ'') be a measure space, and ''f'' a [[measurable function]] with real or complex values on ''S''. The [[cumulative distribution function|distribution function]] of ''f'' is defined for ''t'' > 0 by :<math>\lambda_f(t) = \mu\left\{x\in S: |f(x)| > t\right\}</math>
If ''f'' is in ''L''<sup>''p''</sup>(''S'', ''μ'') for some ''p'' with 1 ≤ ''p'' < ∞, then by [[Markov's inequality]], :<math>\lambda_f(t)\le \frac{\|f\|_p^p}{t^p}</math>
A function ''f'' is said to be in the space '''weak ''L<sup>p</sup>''(''S'', ''μ'')''', or ''L<sup>p,w</sup>''(''S'', ''μ''), if there is a constant ''C'' > 0 such that, for all ''t'' > 0, :<math>\lambda_f(t) \le \frac{C^p}{t^p}</math>
The best constant ''C'' for this inequality is the ''L<sup>p,w</sup>''-norm of ''f'', and is denoted by :<math>\|f\|_{p,w} = \sup_{t > 0} ~ t \lambda_f^{1/p}(t)</math>
The weak ''L''<sup>''p''</sup> coincide with the [[Lorentz space]]s ''L''<sup>''p'',∞</sup>, so this notation is also used to denote them.
The ''L<sup>p,w</sup>''-norm is not a true norm, since the [[triangle inequality]] fails to hold. Nevertheless, for ''f'' in ''L''<sup>''p''</sup>(''S'', ''μ''), :<math>\|f\|_{p,w}\le \|f\|_p</math> and in particular ''L<sup>p</sup>''(''S'', ''μ'') ⊂ ''L<sup>p,w</sup>''(''S'', ''μ'').
In fact, one has
<math>\| f \|^p_{L^p} = \int |f(x)|^p d\mu(x) \geq \int_{\{|f(x)| > t \}} t^p + \int_{\{|f(x)| \leq t \}} |f|^p \geq t^p \mu(\{|f| > t \})</math>,
and raising to power <math>1/p</math> and taking the supremum in <math>t</math> one has
<math>\|f\|_{L^p} \geq \sup_{t > 0} t \; \mu(\{|f| > t \})^{1/p} = \|f\|_{L^{p,w}} </math>.
Under the convention that two functions are equal if they are equal ''μ'' almost everywhere, then the spaces ''L''<sup>p,w</sup> are complete {{harv|Grafakos|2004}}.
For any 0 < ''r'' < ''p'' the expression :<math>||| f |||_{L^{p,\infty}}=\sup_{0<\mu(E)<\infty} \mu(E)^{-1/r + 1/p} \left(\int_E |f|^r\,d\mu\right)^{1/r}</math> is comparable to the ''L<sup>p,w</sup>''-norm. Further in the case ''p'' > 1, this expression defines a norm if ''r'' = 1. Hence for ''p'' > 1 the weak ''L''<sup>''p''</sup> spaces are [[Banach space]]s {{harv|Grafakos|2004}}.
A major result that uses the ''L<sup>p,w</sup>''-spaces is the [[Marcinkiewicz interpolation|Marcinkiewicz interpolation theorem]], which has broad applications to [[harmonic analysis]] and the study of [[singular integrals]].
==Weighted ''L<sup>p</sup>'' spaces== As before, consider a [[measure space]] {{math|(''S'', Σ, ''μ'')}}. Let {{math|''w'' : ''S'' → [0, ∞)}} be a measurable function. The {{mvar|w}}-'''weighted {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} space''' is defined as {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''S'', ''w'' d''μ'')}}, where {{math|''w'' d''μ''}} means the measure {{mvar|ν}} defined by
:<math>\nu (A) \equiv \int_A w(x) \, \mathrm{d} \mu (x), \qquad A \in \Sigma,</math>
or, in terms of the [[Radon–Nikodym theorem|Radon–Nikodym derivative]], {{math|''w'' {{=}} {{sfrac|d''ν''|d''μ''}} }} the [[norm (mathematics)|norm]] for {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''S'', ''w'' d''μ'')}} is explicitly
:<math>\| u \|_{L^p (S, w \, \mathrm{d} \mu)} \equiv \left( \int_S w(x) |u(x)|^p \, \mathrm{d} \mu (x) \right)^{1/p}</math>
As {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}}-spaces, the weighted spaces have nothing special, since {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''S'', ''w'' d''μ'')}} is equal to {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''S'', d''ν'')}}. But they are the natural framework for several results in harmonic analysis {{harv|Grafakos|2004}}<!--Please check this reference. Appears in Grafakos "Modern Fourier analysis", Chapter 9.-->; they appear for example in the [[Muckenhoupt weights|Muckenhoupt theorem]]: for {{math|1 < ''p'' < ∞}}, the classical [[Hilbert transform]] is defined on {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''('''T''', ''λ'')}} where {{math|'''T'''}} denotes the unit circle and {{mvar|λ}} the Lebesgue measure; the (nonlinear) [[Hardy–Littlewood maximal operator]] is bounded on {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''('''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>, ''λ'')}}. Muckenhoupt's theorem describes weights {{mvar|w}} such that the Hilbert transform remains bounded on {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''('''T''', ''w'' d''λ'')}} and the maximal operator on {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''('''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>, ''w'' d''λ'')}}.
=={{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} spaces on manifolds== One may also define spaces {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''(''M'')}} on a manifold, called the '''intrinsic {{math|''L<sup>p</sup>''}} spaces''' of the manifold, using [[Density on a manifold|densities]].

'''Meilutė Julija Lukšienė–Matjošaitytė''' (August 20, 1913 [[Vienna, Austria]] – October 16, 2009 [[Vilnius, Lithuania]]) was a [[Lithuania]]n [[cultural historian]] and [[activist]].<ref name=rytas/> She was a founding member of the [[Sąjūdis]], a [[political organization]] which advocated for the [[independence]] of Lithuania from the [[Soviet Union]] during the late 1980s and early 1990s.
Lukšienė originates from a famous family active in the Lithuanian culture. She obtained her formal education in inter-war period in Lithuania – in 1931 graduated from Vilnius Vytautas Magnus Gymnasium, in 1942 graduated from the Humanitarian Faculty at Kaunas Vytautas Magnus University, obtained Lithuanian literature history speciality (major) and Lithuanian language critic, French literature, Pedagogics specialities (subsidiary). Lukšienė defended two dissertations: of humanitarian science and doctor habilitatus in social science (sphere of education science). A home of Meilė Lukšienė was full of great respect for the human idea, perception, consciousness and inquiring mind. Her husband Kazimieras Lukša (1906–1983) in the independent Republic of Lithuania was a high economic relations officer, high-level Lithuanian bank employee. From 1940 to 1970 Kazimieras Lukša had been teaching the science of balance, economic analysis and international trade courses at Vilnius University. From 1945 to 1946 he was a dean of the faculty of economics. They brought up three children: Dr. Hab. of history [[Ingė Lukšaitė]], the organist [[Giedrė Lukšaitė-Mrázková]], who is a professor of the faculty of music of the [[Academy of Performing Arts in Prague]] and a son Rimtis Lukša, who is a doctor of Natural Sciences.
'''Professional activities'''
Lukšienė is an author and co-author of numerous educational publications and educational strategic documents, she was employed as a teacher, university educator, and during 1951–1958 was a head of the Lithuanian Literature Department of Vilnius University. Lukšienė was accused of nationalism and anti-Soviet standpoint and was dismissed from the university, deprived of right to conduct research on literature. In year 1959 she was employed at Pedagogics (Education) Science Research Institute as a senior research fellow and served there until 1997.
In 1988 Lukšienė, being one of the most outstanding authorities among the Lithuanian scholars, was elected a member of initiative group of the emerging Reform Movement of Lithuania – Sąjūdis – the one to turn into the most important power of Lithuania to restore the independent statehood in 1990. She rallied a group of Lithuania Republic Education Reform, acted as one of the most important creators of the first independent Concept of Lithuanian Education and the related education documents. She nourished the young generation of education science scholars and the managers of education. She paid immense attention to the education principles new to the Lithuanian society – humanism, democracy, national identity – their introduction and dissemination at public discussions and the mass media, the interrelations between the education and culture. The scientist made every effort to raise many gifted education managers and scientists involved in the development of practical educational change strategies that meet the democratic aspirations of education.
'''Awards'''
In year 1989 Meilė Lukšienė was awarded the title of emeritus scientific actor. In 1994 – the 5th Class Order of the Lithuanian Grand Duke Gediminas. In 2003 she was awarded the Great Cross of the Knight Commander of Vytautas Magnus. In 2004 Meilė Lukšienė was awarded the Jan Amos COMENIUS UNESCO medal for her personal contribution in the scientific and practical fortifying education as the basis of creating the state. The significance of her works proves M. Lukšienė to be a scholar of European orientation and global level; a personality, who has significantly contributed to the development of democratic society and modern education and in 2007 she was given an Honourable award by the Ministry of Education and Science.
Meilė Lukšienė was the first in Lithuania to scientifically base the methodology of democratic education based both on historical and the contemporary development aspects. Her scientific creations are characterised by the integral humanitarian and social sciences principle, which continues its immense impact on the education theory science development.
The scholar related the development of Lithuanian pedagogical thought with the general issues of the national culture. Thus her investigations were distinguished for their culturology aspects and extensive viewpoint. Her scientific works were conducted on the verge of three fields of science – pedagogy, literature and culturology, and surpassed the prevailing investigations of those times, concentrated on the narrow specific issues of school system, didactics. Meilė Lukšienė raised essential questions of the orientation of the Lithuanian education system, namely: ratio of nationality and universality; education of cultural identity; continuation of the cultural tradition and modernization of education; social justice. Then she formulated the ideal of education, which served as basis for the new content of education at school: a person who is moral, active citizen, independent thinker, creative and able to intake a variety of cultural values and act in a constructive way. The public discussions of these topics turned into an important factor of the change of pedagogic mentality and the overall mentality of the society. A valuable trait of M. Lukšienė was her ability to get and embrace the newest information from a variety of sources, analyse the Western Europe education systems and the tendencies of their development, the newest ideas of education science, and to foresee the ways of their application in Lithuanian context. Meilė Lukšienė was able to communicate, to read in several languages – the Lithuanian, Polish, French, Russian, and German, thus was non-formally, intensively learning from a variety of sources of literature worldwide. Meilė Lukšienė had a characteristic deep systems-oriented thinking. In all investigations conducted she considered the independent education system to be among the guarantees of statehood, while the presence of direction, purpose and capacity to embrace all possible layers of the society by the education system – one of the conditions for successful existence of the state.
Meilė Lukšienė merited a lot as during the restoration of Lithuanian independence in year 1990 Lithuanian education met already having a conceptual Europe-orientated future education model. It was used as a basis to create the General Concept of Education in Lithuania (1992), which delineated the directions of the national education system development. The essential education principles chosen were humanism, democracy, national identity and renewal. The theoretical basis for education development the humanistic education paradigm, the holistic education concept was chosen. The education system was based on European culture values – personal worth, natural equality of people, freedom of consciousness, tolerance, democratic relations within society. The education was titled as the basic factor of the society development, the fundament of all social reforms, thus a task was formulated to overtake the general development of the society and be its leader. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) experts in year 1999 assessed the Lithuanian education and admitted that in Lithuania does exist a solid conceptual basis for reforms (“There is a strong conceptual foundation for reforms”) and Lithuania presents the best example of the major document – the General Concept of Education in Lithuania of 1992 – its creation and development. The main author of these works is Dr. Hab. Meilė Lukšienė. In her public and educational activities Meilė Lukšienė always was distinctive by her faith that a person has capacity to change oneself and his/her social cultural environment towards humanism. By her overall activities she modelled not only education, but also the future of the state – a modern Lithuanian nation, open society, democratic state. She considered the education of a competent person for a democratic state to be among the major goals of education. Besides, the researcher always considered competence to be not the narrow professional qualifications of the subject matter, but the overall readiness to actively operate in a society, be responsible for the life in the society, create its culture, to regularly react to the challenges of the development in the world and its changes, thus get ready for lifelong learning. The approach of M. Lukšienė is in special resound with European and global orientation of education of the 21st century and the goals of educational systems.
The significance of her works proves M. Lukšienė to be a scholar of European orientation and global level; a personality, who has significantly contributed to the development of democratic society and modern education. 100th anniversary of the birth of Meilė Lukšienė, professor and social scientist (1913-2009) is celebrated by UNESCO. The celebration of the 100th anniversary of the birth of Meilė Lukšienė, winner of the 2004 UNESCO Jan Amos Comenius Medal, would highlight the role of culture in education. Her contributions are important in raising cultural awareness with modernization of education and social justice, and continue to influence development of education, science, and culture in Lithuania.
Meilė Lukšienė died on October 16, 2009 in [[Vilnius, Lithuania]], at the age of 97.<ref name=rytas>{{cite news|first= |last= |title=Mirė literatūrologė, kultūros istorikė, edukologė M.J.Lukšienė |url=http://m.lrytas.lt/-12556801411254590040-mir%C4%97-literat%C5%ABrolog%C4%97-kult%C5%ABros-istorik%C4%97-edukolog%C4%97-m-j-luk%C5%A1ien%C4%97.htm |work=[[Lietuvos rytas]] |publisher= |date=2009-10-16 |accessdate=2009-11-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722151654/http://m.lrytas.lt/-12556801411254590040-mir%C4%97-literat%C5%ABrolog%C4%97-kult%C5%ABros-istorik%C4%97-edukolog%C4%97-m-j-luk%C5%A1ien%C4%97.htm |archivedate=2011-07-22 |df= }}</ref>

[[File:Christopher Walken - 1984.jpg|thumb|Actor [[Christopher Walken]] performing a monologue in the 1984 stage play ''[[Hurlyburly]]'']] In [[theatre]], a '''monologue''' (from {{lang-el|μονόλογος}}, from μόνος ''mónos'', "alone, solitary" and λόγος ''lógos'', "speech") is a speech presented by a single [[character (arts)|character]], most often to express their mental thoughts aloud, though sometimes also to directly address another character or the [[audience]]. Monologues are common across the range of dramatic media ([[Play (theatre)|play]]s, [[film]]s,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/list/ls000000354/|title=The Greatest Movie Speeches/Monologues of all time!|author=|date=|website=IMDb|accessdate=29 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160401000758/http://www.imdb.com/list/ls000000354/|archivedate=1 April 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> etc.), as well as in non-dramatic media such as [[poetry]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.victorianweb.org/authors/rb/dm1.html |title=Dramatic Monologue: An Introduction |publisher=Victorianweb.org |date=2003-03-10 |accessdate=2013-08-16 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130807215608/http://www.victorianweb.org/authors/rb/dm1.html |archivedate=7 August 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Monologues share much in common with several other literary devices including [[Soliloquy|soliloquies]], [[Apostrophe (figure of speech)|apostrophes]], and [[asides|asides]]. There are, however, distinctions between each of these devices.
==Similar literary devices== Monologues are similar to [[Poetry|poems]], epiphanies, and others, in that, they involve one 'voice' speaking but there are differences between them. For example, a soliloquy involves a character relating his or her thoughts and feelings to him/herself and to the audience without addressing any of the other characters. A monologue is the thoughts of a person spoken out loud.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/soliloquy |title=Soliloquy – Definition and More from the Free Merriam-Webster Dictionary |publisher=Merriam-webster.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130706041614/http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/soliloquy |archivedate=6 July 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Monologues are also distinct from apostrophes, in which the speaker or writer addresses an imaginary person, inanimate object, or idea.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web |url=http://www.pleasanton.k12.ca.us/fhsweb/thoeb/RomeoandJuliet.htm |title=The Tragedy of Romeo and Juliet by William Shakespeare |publisher=Pleasanton.k12.ca.us |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130902062728/http://www.pleasanton.k12.ca.us/fhsweb/thoeb/RomeoandJuliet.htm |archivedate=2 September 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Asides differ from each of these not only in length (asides are shorter) but also in that asides are not heard by other characters even in situations where they logically should be (e.g. two characters engaging in a [[dialogue]] interrupted by one of them delivering an aside).<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
==History== In ancient Greek theatre, the origin of western drama,{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}} the conventional three actor rule was preceded by a two actor rule, which was itself preceded by a convention in which only a single actor would appear on stage, along with the chorus.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kuritz|first=Paul|title=The Making of Theatre History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cS6JV4Z27DoC|accessdate=27 May 2014|year=1988|isbn=978-0-13-547861-5}}</ref> The origin of the monologue as a dramatic device, therefore, is not rooted in dialogue. It is, instead, the other way around; dialogue evolved from monologue.
Ancient Roman theatre featured monologues extensively, more commonly than either Ancient Greek theatre or modern theatre.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Link Monologues in Roman Comedy |author=Henry W. Prescott |journal=Classical Philology |volume=34 |issue=1 |date=January 1939 |pages=1–23|jstor=264065}}</ref> One of the key purposes of these monologues was to indicate the passage of significant amounts of time (that would be tedious to actually play out in real time) within scenes. This type of monologue is referred to as a linking monologue.<ref name="jstor1">{{cite journal|title=Link Monologues in Roman Comedy |author=Henry W. Prescott |journal=Classical Philology |volume=34 |issue=2 |date=April 1939 |pages=116–126|jstor=264823}}</ref> Other monologue types included "entrance monologues"<ref name="jstor1"/> and exit monologues.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Exit Monologues in Roman Comedy |author=Henry W. Prescott |journal=Classical Philology|volume=37 |issue=1 |date=January 1942 |pages=1–21 |jstor=264367}}</ref> In each of these cases a primary function is indicating the passage of time.<ref name="jstor1"/>
From Renaissance theatre onward, monologues generally focused on characters using the extended speech to pursue their dramatic need. Postmodern theatre, on the other hand, often embraces the performative aspects of the monologue, even to the point of challenging the boundary between character portrayal (e.g. acting) and autobiographical speeches.<ref>{{cite book|last=Geis|first=Deborah R.|title=Postmodern theatric(k)s: monologue in contemporary American drama|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AiJaAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=27 May 2014|date=December 1993|publisher=[[University of Michigan Press]]|isbn=978-0-472-10467-3}}</ref>
==Types== Interior monologues involve a character externalizing their thoughts so that the audience can witness experiences that would otherwise be mostly internal. In contrast, a dramatic monologue involves one character speaking to another character.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/389899/monologue |title=monologue (drama and literature) - Encyclopædia Britannica |publisher=Britannica.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130812133304/http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/389899/monologue |archivedate=12 August 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Monologues can also be divided along the lines of active and narrative monologues. In an active monologue a character is using their speech to achieve a clear goal. Narrative monologues simply involve a character telling a story and can often be identified by the fact that they are in the past tense.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.angelfire.com/ego/westmontdrama/MonologueInfo.html |title=Monologue Information |publisher=Angelfire.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-16 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028033907/http://www.angelfire.com/ego/westmontdrama/MonologueInfo.html |archivedate=28 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Auditions== Actors in theatre, and sometimes in film and television, may be asked to deliver monologues in auditions. Audition monologues demonstrate an actor's ability to prepare a piece and deliver a performance.<ref>{{cite web|title=Audition Monologues|url=http://www.ace-your-audition.com/free-monologues.html|website=Ace Your Audition|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100714084548/http://www.ace-your-audition.com/free-monologues.html|archivedate=14 July 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> These pieces are usually limited to two minutes or less and are often paired with a contrasting monologue: comic and dramatic; classical and contemporary. The choice of monologues for an audition<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dailyactor.com/contemporary-monologues/|title=Monologues from Movies & Plays|last=|first=|date=October 4, 2018|website=Daily Actor|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> often depends on the play or role. The audition monologue is a rite of passage with theatre actors.

In an educational milieu '''MSIP''' can be defined as the either the ''[http://www.msip.ca/ Manitoba School Improvement Plan]'' or the '''Multi-Subject Instructional Period'''. For the purpose of this article the acronym MSIP will be used exclusively to refer to the multi-subject instructional period.<ref name="ML">Miller, Leanne. (2003). Ensuring [[Literacy#Reading_comprehension|Literacy]] in an Age of Scrutiny. Professionally Speaking <{{cite web |url=http://www.oct.ca/publications/professionally_speaking/december_2003/literacy_at_risk.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-02-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070710220109/http://www.oct.ca/publications/professionally_speaking/december_2003/literacy_at_risk.asp |archivedate=2007-07-10 |df= }}></ref>
The Manitoba School Improvement Project dates from 1991, when it was established as a result of the vision of the [https://web.archive.org/web/20090221011000/http://www.gordonfn.org/ Walter and Duncan Gordon Foundation], a Canadian charitable foundation. The Foundation was interested in enhancing education for "students at risk" and needed a province with an educational community that would welcome and support their involvement. The [[Province of Manitoba]] met their criteria and a pilot program was begun. Established initially with a very definite [[Urban area|urban]] focus, the program has in recent years expanded to not only include the province's [[rural]] community but other [[Canada|Canadian]] jurisdictions.<ref>[http://www.umanitoba.ca/publications/cjeap/articles/harris.html Successful School Improvement in the United Kingdom and Canada<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
MSIP promotes an alternative academic schedule for high [[school]] students. Students in [[Canada]] generally attend high schools where the school year is divided into two semesters consisting of four period days. Class time can vary slightly but most classes last between 70 and 76 minutes. Instead of the standard four 75-minute periods found in the semestered school MSIP schools adopt five 60-minute periods including one 60-minute multi-subject instructional period.
==How MSIP works==
Students attend their regular four classes each day plus a one-hour supervised MSIP class. Students in any one MSIP class are arranged in multi-grade formation with varied levels of ability. Their [[Course (education)|course]] selections determine their timetable and where the MSIP class will fall. In many cases the MSIP class begins with 20 minutes of silent [[Literacy#Reading_comprehension|literacy]] work - reading or writing complimenting the movement to improve literacy skills. The rest of the period students may use for work on assignments, make up work they missed due to absences or get help in areas where they are falling behind.<ref name="ML" /> Students have the ability to move within the school environment during their MSIP period to seek extra help, use computer and research resources, attend [[School counselor|guidance counselling]] appointments and meet with subject teachers where possible. The flexibility of this format alleviates the disruption normally associated with the typical semesterted schedule.<ref name=autogenerated1>LaSalle Field Study 2003: LaSalle Secondary School, Kingston Ontario. Interviews and personal conversations with staff and teachers.</ref>
==Structural Benefits== '''Resources:''' MSIP increases students’ access to learning resources. During their MSIP, students are allowed to travel to an area like a computer lab to do [[research]], to a science lab to complete an assignment, or see a teacher for academic support. MSIP schools report that on any given period approximately 5% of students travel to an area outside of the MSIP class. Schools experiencing timetabling difficulties due to a shortage of lab space and gymnasium facilities have in effect created more facility opportunities with this 5 period system.
'''Timetable Conflicts:''' One of the early goals of the MSIP schedule was to deal with the increased number of conflicts students were experiencing in a shrinking school. Having 5 slots to place classes reduces the probability of class overlaps.
==Educational Benefits==
Studies of existing MSIP schools show improvement in students' [[Critical thinking|inductive thinking abilities]], improved group interactions skills and an improvement in students’ abilities to memorize information.<ref>Harris, A. (2003). Behind the classroom door: The challenge of organisational and pedagogical change. Journal of Educational Change, 4, 369-382.</ref> For many non-academic students MSIP also provides shorter classes making it easier for students to focus and complete homework in their MSIP class before going home.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
[[Student-centred learning|Student-Centered Learning]] is a by-product of the MSIP period. The MSIP format demands that students be self-directed and organized each day by creating an environment of student autonomy - students are in charge of their own agenda. [[Homework]], [[research]] and even group meetings are scheduled by the student during their MSIP period. This results in an increased level of responsibility and ownership over their own [[learning]].
'''Mastering Learning''': Research emphasizes the need for “do time” for consolidation of learning; MSIP provides this time. Each day students will have 60 minutes of ‘do time’ to complete homework, prepare for tests, and work on projects and assignments. This time will promote ‘mastering’ learning and prepare students to learn new concepts and skills, thus improving overall performance.<ref>http://www.dsbn.edu.on.ca/Schools/GovSimcoe/msip.pdf</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = Murder-Set-Pieces | image = Murder-Set-Pieces.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical poster cover | director = [[Nick Palumbo]] | producer = Nick Palumbo | writer = Nick Palumbo | starring = {{Plainlist| * Sven Garrett * [[Gunnar Hansen]] * [[Cerina Vincent]] * [[Tony Todd]] }} | music = {{Plainlist| * [[The Bronx Casket Co.]] * Eric Galligan * The Giallos Flame * [[Necrophagia]] * [[Zombi (band)|Zombi]] }} | cinematography = Brendan Flynt | editing = Todd C. Ramsay | studio = Fright Flix Productions | distributor = Blackwatch Releasing | released = {{Film date|2004|12|04|[[Sitges Film Festival]]|2004|12|24}} | runtime = {{Plainlist| * '''[[List of NC-17 rated films|NC-17]] theatrical cut:''' * 105 minutes * '''[[Director's cut|Director's Cut]]:''' * 91 minutes * '''Edited cut:''' * 83 minutes }} | country = United States | language = {{Plainlist| * English * German }} | budget = $2 million }} '''''Murder-Set-Pieces''''' is a 2004 American [[horror film]] written, produced, and directed by [[Nick Palumbo]].<ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/2004-12-28/film/film/ Village Voice - Ben Kenigsberg]</ref> The film stars Sven Garrett and features cameos from horror icons [[Gunnar Hansen]] (''[[The Texas Chain Saw Massacre]]''), [[Cerina Vincent]] (''[[Cabin Fever (2002 film)|Cabin Fever]]''), and [[Tony Todd]] (''[[Candyman (film)|Candyman]]'').
==Plot== {{expand section|date=October 2014}} The film follows a wealthy immigrant [[serial killer]]: a [[Germans|German]] photographer, who leads a double life: by day he shoots erotic photos. By night, he rapes, tortures, and murders prostitutes.<ref>[http://www.filmtipps.at/films/msp.php FILMTIPPS.at - Murder-Set-Pieces]</ref>
==Cast== * Sven Garrett as The Photographer * [[Gunnar Hansen]] as Nazi mechanic * [[Cerina Vincent]] as Beautiful girl * [[Tony Todd]] as Clerk<ref>[http://www.dvduncut.com/product_info.php/products_id/6202 Murder Set Pieces (uncut) :: DVD-Shop - dvduncut.com]</ref> * Jade Risser as Jade * [[Edwin Neal]] as Good Samaritan
==Censorship== In comparison with the theatrical cut of the film, the 'R' rated DVD version was missing approximately 22 minutes.<ref>[http://www.frightflix.com/ Fright Flix Productions, Inc. - Murder-Set-Pieces]</ref> Most of the cuts were to obtain the 'R' rating and removed several intense scenes of sexualized violence and torture, however, some scenes were also removed by the director himself which he intended to edit out of the film before going into theaters but never got the chance.<ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/2005/0107/p14s01-almo.html Christian Science Monitor - David Sterritt]</ref>
===UK ban=== The film was submitted for release in the [[United Kingdom]] to the [[British Board of Film Classification]] (BBFC) who refused to give the film an '18' certificate, therefore making the film illegal to supply within the UK. The BBFC stated they rejected the film because of sexual violence, and the film was potentially breaking UK obscenity laws.<ref>http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/murder-set-pieces-1970</ref>
==Release== ''Murder-Set-Pieces'' was given a [[limited release]] on December 24, 2004 with an [[NC-17 rating]].{{dubious|1="self-appointed NC-17 rating"|date=October 2015}} The film was released by [[Lions Gate Home Entertainment]] with an 'R' rating on DVD.<ref name=VarietyHarvey>{{cite news |last=Harvey |first=Dennis |date=December 27, 2004 |title=Review: ‘Murder-Set-Pieces’ |url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117925784.html?categoryId=31&cs=1 |newspaper=Variety |access-date=October 19, 2015}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=October 2015 <!-- No discussion of DVD release or rating in cited source -->}}
The film was released by [[Universal Studios]] in Spain, [[The Weinstein Company]] in Sweden, [[20th Century Fox]] in France, and [[Anchor Bay Entertainment]] in Russia.<ref>[https://www.myspace.com/murdersetpieces Official MySpace]</ref>
===Critical reception=== {{expand section|date=October 2015}} The film received generally negative reviews. [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports that 36% of 11 reviews were positive, with an average rating of 3.7/10.<ref>{{rotten-tomatoes|murder_set_pieces|Murder-Set-Pieces}} Retrieved February 18, 2014.</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a 13 out of 100 rating, based on 5 critics, signifying "overwhelming dislike".<ref>{{metacritic film|murder-set-pieces|Murder-Set-Pieces}} Retrieved February 18, 2014.</ref>
Debra Birnbaum of the ''[[New York Post]]'' wrote it "aspires to be a highly stylized exploration of the mind of a serial killer, but it's nothing more than a gory, blood-soaked snuff film, reveling in its own shock value."<ref>{{cite news |last=Birnbaum |first=Debra |date=January 7, 2005 |title=Awful Murder Flick Not Worth Film It's Shot On |url=https://nypost.com/2005/01/07/awful-murder-flick-not-worth-film-its-shot-on/ |newspaper=New York Post |access-date=October 19, 2015}}</ref>
Dennis Harvey of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' said the film evinced "only the slightest interest in narrative or character," and "distinguishes itself via sheer extremity of gore, sadism and tastelessness", and that its "nastiness is so insistent, one-dimensional and excessive it risks self-parody."<ref name=VarietyHarvey/>
Ben Kenigsberg of ''[[The Village Voice]]'' called it "a movie so utterly degenerate it makes you wish that indie filmmakers had to prove a basic standard of decency in order to buy a camera."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Kenigsberg |first1=Ben|title=Tracking Shots: Murder-Set-Pieces |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/film/0501,kenigsberg,59780,20.html |accessdate=October 19, 2015 |work=Village Voice |date=January 4, 2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050105160109/http://www.villagevoice.com/film/0501,kenigsberg,59780,20.html |archivedate=January 5, 2005}}</ref>
However, Heidi Martinuzzi of ''[[Film Threat]]'' gave it four stars out of four, calling it "incredibly good" and "well made."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Martinuzzi |first1=Heidi |title=Murder-Set-Pieces |url=http://www.filmthreat.com/reviews/6643/ |website=[[Film Threat]] |accessdate=October 19, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120919163613/http://www.filmthreat.com/reviews/6643/ |archivedate=September 19, 2012 |date=January 18, 2005}}</ref>
===Home media=== A [[director's cut]] [[DVD]] was released after its theatrical run. The theatrical version runs at 105 minutes, the uncut DVD version runs at 91 minutes, whereas the 'R' rated version runs at 83 minutes.<ref>[http://www.yourjournal.de/artikel/528-murder-set-pieces.html Murder Set Pieces - Yourjournal.de]</ref>

{{Orphan|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox diagnostic | name = Nasoendoscopy | image = | alt = | caption = | pronounce = |purpose = exam of the nose | synonyms = | reference_range = | calculator = | DiseasesDB = <!--{{DiseasesDB2|numeric_id}}--> | ICD10 = <!--{{ICD10|Group|Major|minor|LinkGroup|LinkMajor}} or {{ICD10PCS|code|char1/char2/char3/char4}}--> | ICD9 = | ICDO = | MedlinePlus = <!--article_number--> | eMedicine = <!--article_number--> | MeshID = | OPS301 = <!--{{OPS301|code}}--> | LOINC = <!--{{LOINC|code}}--> }} In speech pathology and medicine, '''nasoendoscopy''' is the [[endoscopy|endoscopic]] examination of the [[velopharynx]], or the [[nose]], often with a [[CCD camera]] or a [[fiber optic]] camera on a flexible tube passed through the [[nostril]]. It can provide information to evaluate speech and velopharyngeal function or dysfunction, as in diseases such as [[nasopharynx cancer|sinonasal carcinomas]].<ref>Pegoraro-Krook M. I., Dutka-Souza J. C., Marino V. C. (2008.) "Nasoendoscopy of velopharynx before and during diagnostic therapy", ''J App Oral Sci'', 16(3):181-8.</ref><ref>Seikel J. A., King D. W., Drumright D. G. (2010.) [https://books.google.com/books?id=LFBOhaD1JHwC&pg=PA290&lpg=PA290&dq=nasoendoscopy&source=bl&ots=9Gx0-yTIMo&sig=-1eUHWlu4ExSargCQ42ZfTzBRj8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=VabzUfXPO4zjkgWb3YHoBw&ved=0CM4BEOgBMB8#v=onepage&q=nasoendoscopy&f=false ''Anatomy & Physiology for Speech, Language, and Hearing''], Cengage Learning, p. 290.</ref>
==Procedure==
===Indications=== After removal of nasal packing following [[epistaxis]], routine nasoendoscopy is not necessarily indicated.<ref>Makarawo T. P., Howe D., Chan S. K. (2011.) "Is routine nasoendoscopy warranted in epistaxis patients after removal of nasal packing?", ''Allergy Rhinol'', 2(1):12-5.</ref> However, widely accepted indications for nasoendoscopy include:<ref>[http://www.whitememorial.com/medical-services/nasoendoscopy-procedure Nasoendoscopy Procedure - White Memorial Medical Center]</ref> *abnormal speech characteristics: hypernasal resonance, excessive nasal airflow including nasal air escape and nasal turbulence (also called nasal rustle), and absence of or weak intra-oral air pressure for oral pressure consonants; *limited progress with speech therapy to establish oral pressure sounds; *difficulty maintaining intra-oral air pressure and velopharyngeal closure during speech; *patient has known or suspected abnormality of palate or velopharynx; and, *patient is being considered for pharyngoplasty, maxillary advancement or speech prosthesis.
===Contraindications, complications, and safety=== No absolute contraindications exist for nasoendoscopy; and, while the procedure is relatively safe, the exact risk of the procedure depends on the skill and experience of the endoscope operator.<ref>Tabaee A., Hsu A. K., Kacker A. (2011.) "Indications, technique, safety, and accuracy of office-based nasal endoscopy with biopsy for sinonasal neoplasm", ''Int Forum Allergy Rhinol'', 1(3):225-8.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

[[Image:Festival Folclórico de Parintins.jpg|300px|right]] '''Parintins Folklore Festival''' (''Festival Folclórico de Parintins'') is a popular annual celebration held in the Brazilian city of [[Parintins]], [[Amazonas State, Brazil|Amazonas]]. It is one of the largest the annual festival in [[Brazil]];<ref name="NYT2">{{cite press release | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/08/arts/dance/deborah-colker-choreographer-rio-olympics-opening-ceremony-dance.html | title=For This Choreographer, the Olympics Are the Zenith | publisher=The New York Times | date=August 7, 2016 | accessdate=15 February 2017}}</ref> only the [[Brazilian Carnival|Carnival]] festivities in [[Rio de Janeiro]] and [[Salvador, Bahia|Salvador]] draw more participants.
Often called ''Festival do Boi-Bumbá'', [[Bumba Meu Boi]], or simply ''Festival'', the event takes place during three days in late June. The festival celebrates a local [[legend]] about a resurrected ox. It is also a competition where two teams, ''Garantido'' and ''Caprichoso,'' compete in extended retellings of the story, each team attempting to outdo the other with flamboyant dances, singing, and [[Float (parade)|parade floats]]. Each team has to complete its show within two and a half hours. A team that does not follow this time limit is subjected to points penalties. Each nightly performance is largely based on local Amazonian [[folklore]] and [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous]] culture, but also incorporates contemporary Brazilian rhythms and themes.<ref name="O Globo (Brazil)">{{cite web | url=http://blogs.oglobo.globo.com/george-vidor/post/viva-parintins.html | title=Viva Parintins | publisher=O Globo (Brazil) | work=George Vidor | date=July 4, 2016 | language=Portuguese | accessdate=February 15, 2017}}</ref><ref name="NYT">{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/09/19/travel/frugal-traveler-an-amazon-cruise-turns-into-a-party.html | title=FRUGAL TRAVELER; An Amazon Cruise Turns Into a Party | publisher=The New York Times | date=September 19, 1999 | accessdate=February 15, 2017 | author=MCLANESEP, Daisann}}</ref> The place where the teams present themselves is called "Bumbódromo", a round, grounded stage. The "Bumbódromo" supports 35.000 people in the audience.<ref name="ABC News">{{cite web | url=http://abcnews.go.com/Travel/story?id=118890&page=1 | title=Parintins Folk Festival in Brazil | publisher=ABC News | date=July 19, 2000 | accessdate=February 15, 2017 | author=DARLINGTON, Shasta}}</ref>
Despite the importance of the celebration to the [[Amazonas State, Brazil|Amazonas]] region of Brazil, this festival was not widely known in other parts of the country until the musical group [[Carrapicho]] released the hit ''Bate forte o tambor'' in 1996.
It is common for local people to tell the visitors that Parintins is the only place in the World where [[Coca-Cola]] ads are [[blue]]. While it is true that within the Bumbódromo there are Coca-Cola ads in both red and blue, there are other instances of Coca-Cola ads reflecting the colors of sporting teams. During the 2011 Festival do Boi-Bumbá, Coca-Cola was available throughout [[Amazonas (Brazilian state)|Amazonas]] region in special edition cans that were half red, half blue.
